standards.benchmark: Use latitude and longitude coordinates to understand the relationship between people and places on the Earth.
standards.item_specs: Students use coordinate systems to locate places and understand spatial relationships.
essential_questions: How do we describe locations on Earth?
learning_targets: I can use latitude and longitude to locate places.
I can explain the relationship between location and human activity.
I can read and interpret maps using coordinates.
standards.sample_assessment: A location at 30°N, 90°W is in which hemisphere? A) Northern and Western B) Southern and Eastern C) Northern and Eastern D) Southern and Western

standards.benchmark: Explain how major physical characteristics, natural resources, climate, and absolute and relative locations have influenced settlement, interactions, and the economies of ancient civilizations of the world.
standards.item_specs: Students analyze how geography influenced ancient civilizations.
essential_questions: How does geography influence where people settle?
What role do natural resources play in civilization development?
learning_targets: I can explain how geography influenced ancient settlements.
I can analyze the relationship between resources and economic development.
I can describe how climate affects human activity.
standards.sample_assessment: Ancient civilizations often developed near rivers because rivers provided: A) Protection from invaders B) Water for irrigation and transportation C) Gold and silver D) Building materials

standards.benchmark: Identify the factors that influence the development of different economic systems throughout the world.
standards.item_specs: Students identify factors that shape economic systems.
essential_questions: What factors determine how an economy develops?
How do different economic systems allocate resources?
learning_targets: I can identify different types of economic systems.
I can explain factors that influence economic development.
I can compare how different systems allocate resources.
standards.sample_assessment: In a command economy, economic decisions are made primarily by: A) Individual consumers B) Private businesses C) The government D) Traditional customs

standards.benchmark: Evaluate how civilizations through clans, tribes, and city-states evolved into larger civilizations through various forms of government.
standards.item_specs: Students analyze the evolution of governmental structures.
learning_targets: I can trace the development of government from tribes to civilizations.
I can explain why governments form.
I can compare different forms of early government.
standards.sample_assessment: City-states like Athens and Sparta are examples of: A) Large empires B) Independent political units C) Tribes D) Clans

standards.item_specs: Students distinguish between and analyze primary and secondary sources.
essential_questions: What is the difference between primary and secondary sources?
How do historians use sources to understand the past?
learning_targets: I can identify primary and secondary sources.
I can analyze sources for reliability and bias.
I can use sources to support historical arguments.
standards.sample_assessment: An ancient Roman coin found by archaeologists is an example of: A) A secondary source B) A primary source C) A biased source D) A modern reproduction

standards.benchmark: Compare the economic, political, social, and religious institutions of ancient river civilizations.
standards.item_specs: Students compare institutions across Mesopotamia, Egypt, India, and China.
essential_questions: What did ancient river civilizations have in common?
How did geography shape each civilization differently?
learning_targets: I can compare the governments of ancient river civilizations.
I can explain how religion influenced ancient societies.
I can analyze economic systems of early civilizations.
standards.sample_assessment: Which feature was common to ALL ancient river valley civilizations? A) Democracy B) Monotheism C) Writing systems D) Iron tools

standards.benchmark: Summarize the important achievements and contributions of ancient Greek civilization.
standards.item_specs: Students identify Greek contributions to Western civilization.
essential_questions: What did ancient Greece contribute to the modern world?
How do Greek ideas influence us today?
learning_targets: I can identify major Greek achievements in government, philosophy, and arts.
I can explain the concept of democracy as developed in Athens.
I can describe Greek contributions to science and mathematics.
standards.sample_assessment: The concept of citizens participating directly in government decisions comes from: A) Ancient Rome B) Ancient Egypt C) Ancient Athens D) Ancient Persia

standards.benchmark: Identify the causes and effects of the fall of the Roman Empire.
standards.item_specs: Students analyze multiple factors contributing to Rome's decline.
essential_questions: Why did the Roman Empire fall?
What were the consequences of Rome's collapse?
learning_targets: I can identify political causes of Rome's fall.
I can explain economic factors that weakened the empire.
I can describe the effects of Rome's fall on Europe.
standards.sample_assessment: Which was NOT a cause of the fall of the Roman Empire? A) Barbarian invasions B) Economic problems C) The rise of Christianity D) Weak leadership
